text: Hey <@U0MKH0BE0> (cc: <@U026PLK4S> and <@U1A1A9L7N>), I am going through your PSD for my content audit and found something that might be confusing to our users <https://www.dropbox.com/s/a5nnc7rshc0sskl/Screenshot%202016-08-03%2009.21.58.png?dl=0>
<@U0260V1BX|melissa> shared a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/melissa/F1XSWGPB8/screenshot_2016-08-03_09.21.58.png|Screenshot 2016-08-03 09.21.58.png>

Typically an empty checkbox doesn’t have a check mark in it. I would recommend removing the check mark on the right-hand screen. The messaging here should also be about opting out of reminders and the default state should be un-checked. That’s not something that needs to be in the comps but its something I’ll communicate in our wires. <https://www.dropbox.com/s/eqh024ajsy4qcke/Screenshot%202016-08-03%2009.21.51.png?dl=0>
<@U0260V1BX|melissa> shared a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/melissa/F1XT90UKT/screenshot_2016-08-03_09.21.51.png|Screenshot 2016-08-03 09.21.51.png>
The white box with no check mark is virtually invisible so it might be worth exploring other treatments that are more visible. stroke  / different color / ?
are there other places where we have similar situation as well?
One of my screens uses a similar checkmark
Lemme dig it up

Yes, there are. Phillip is using this same treatment for the check mark. I was just looking for that treatment in his files. I’ll make sure to change the default state and get in touch with Phillip to see where he’s using it
cool/appreciated. Agreed with the need - just want to make sure we catch it across any other screens. Thanks!
yes good call. thank you all!

Hey guys, could use some input on this, we have an instance of a lighter grey secondary button, but it represents a tappable state rather than an inactive one. We have the grey version of the primary button showing an inactive state which seems to conflict with this. 
1) What is the instance of this grey secondary button and do we feel it warrents a separate style? ( <@U02AUNA0P> or <@U0XCJ372R> )
2) Are there any opinions on an inactive state for secondary buttons that might not be changed to grey like the primary? (maybe removing the stroke and turning the label grey?)

<@U026E0ZNR>: I personally feel like we can get rid of the grey secondary button since I think it’s only used on the home screen. If we remove the grey button, then I would try to use the lightest grey (#C4C4C4) for the inactive state.
I agree with <@U0XCJ372R>
Cool, just talked with Phillip and he said he’ll change his grey secondary buttons.

Leah would you be able to update the global doc to reflect that the grey stroked button at top is supposed to be an inactive state instead? Melodee has a screen example mocked up of this (could you post that here?), we just need to be sure it uses #D7D7D7 the same way our primary inactive button does (instead of the current #8F8F8F).
Yes I can

I'm getting confused. I thought the light grey was #C4C4C4
it is
this #c9c9c9 value is only to accomplish the slight gradient style buttons had been using. the core color is #c4c4c4
instead of applying a gradient layer effect the way PS is using
Ha, got it!

Not sure if this helps, but just my .02. I think the gradient button styles were legacy, and later comps & designs didn’t have it. If we like it, i’m down to keep if for iOS. If it’s creating too much trouble, i’m totally fine with abandoning it and just going with the flat color.
My .02, the gradients are barely noticeable and flats are easy to implement
totally. i think that’s why some comps had it and some didn’t. even harder to tell in printouts. If it’s not too late, I’d say we officially ditch it and update the Style Guide
and like I said, Android can’t implement them

I’m updating it right now
easy enough :thumbsup:

Hey <!channel>, thanks again for kicking ass last week and keeping up with all these changes. Having fresh eyes and talking with Leah/Melissa, we think there are a couple of small moves that can resolve some of the VERY FEW things that we still feel like could use some love. I’m going to post them here. Not sure if we need to update comps, style-guide, or both. Happy to help on any front.

The first resolves the placement the “more info” button for the Discovery Session card. This has been a tough problem to solve, no doubt. We’re thinking that the current placement (off to the side) feels a little wonky. Especially when it’s paired with the “heart” icon the lives on top of the card. I know we were trying to reserve as much card real estate for playing the video, but since we’re breaking that convention with the heart, we might as well do the same for the info. Our idea is that it would look something like this:

<https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/10434419/Screen%20Shot%202016-08-03%20at%201.46.26%20PM.png>

The second removes the icon AND the indent from the level selection screen in discovery settings. We were a little concerned with line length, but also feel like the the color change and button activation is enough affordance to show you what you’ve selected. And we like keeping to our theme of “left-align or die.” (Note to Melodee: I tightened up the spacing between the elements, LMK if you want me  to show you what I did) That would look something like this: 

<https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/10434419/Level-Select.png>
is this change going to work for people who are colorblind?
<@U026PLK4S|matt> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/matt/F1Y214490/pasted_image_at_2016_08_03_03_11_pm.png|Pasted image at 2016-08-03, 3:11 PM>
i would recommend a check mark / other graphic shift in addition to the color shift
for the colorblind issue
question though - are we doing much else to support these types of usability cases?
hm
i just want to make sure we’re not tacking the checkmark back on for this reason only, unless we have a strong case for the types of usability we agree to support and are supporting them elsehwere
I saw it come up previously on a calendar view
It’s also used on completed sessions in lists on the Dx instances (tho much smaller)
<@U026103R3>: to your point this may be a 1.1 thing. We have not done a full accessibility sweep unfortunately, and if we were to i’d also say the same thing about the day selection honeycomb.
but i dont believe there are any other places where we are using solely color as a selected state… off the top of my head anyway

right, i just feel like we’d be making a decision on this one case when we’re not terribly accessibility compliant in other sections. i see all of the points here, but i agree with a sweep looking towards 1.1
that’s fine.
but i do think that if we can find a simple solution for launch we may as well
since we’re making updates anyway.

Re: the new placement of the info icon, I think that’s fine as long as we supply an ample amount of space for the tap target, considering that if they miss tapping for more info, they would launch into an auto playing media session. (Granted, this same concern goes for the heart on the card anyway )

Also I’m saying all this assuming the entire card will be the “play button” target and not just the actual icon. Correct me if we’re doing it differently than that.
^ think that all makes sense trent

also everyone on the colorblindness question - i’ve been chatting with charles and he put me onto a tool where you can test the screen for colorblindness, and that orange should be just fine and legible

melissa i’ll slack you directly

That’s fine Matt, I think the proposed solution is fine if we don’t want it outside the card, I’m bringing light to potential usability concerns so we can be conscious of how we built it. The other thing to keep in mind is that these Hearts will not be there in most cases (if at all for launch)
As far as clarification: Seeing the example has already been made, I’m wondering if there’s anything else needed from me.
Do we need additional full screen mockups to show context? I can def replace any screens with the Info icons outside cards if we would like that.

if it’s not too much trouble, i think it would be worth updating the comps to match this new icon and placement, (and lack of checkmark). especially since we’ll be giving those to the folks making the icons needed. moving forward though, i don’t think we’ll need to go back and update comps. the only thing we’ll need to do is update the UX document that will show visuals to call out any major changes. that make sense?
I'll make that change in dx but I'm wondering are we wanting all the dark text in those sections to be grey?

I feel like if the heart is tap-able, then two icons would also be tap-able. Hard to say until we try it, but thinking about other places where we’re stacking icons horizontally (homescreen) i think we should have enough room for two distinct areas

<!channel> ^ Any comments on loading states? ^ (kat’s question above)

There is a minor loading state on one of my setting screens under tracking activities, and I believe also in Phillip’s add activity screens. I forgot to spec it out, but I’m not sure if that should be in the global spec.
idk that it needs to be spec’d either, depending on what it is. Would just like to know what the direction is because we have content to load on basically every screen, even if it is just locally
also error states

question on the loading of content. <@U026E0ZNR> in your audit of motion needs is that something that is or will be represented? i feel like if we have content to load on every screen, we should have a global loader than can be used in multiple places
I have an entry in my audit for loaders
but nothing more specific than that

it’s fine if that’s a later thing, but in general, it would be nice to know if we hide the screen until we have content to display or if we show the empty state behind a loader until the content actually loads, that sort of thing

Kat let’s maybe have a discussion later around what content loading actually looks like. Whole screen loading sounds like an easy solve but I suspect individual blocks loading in sight may be needed at some point
If I were able to get a better grasp I could have a more informed solution
<@U026E0ZNR> that would be great. A follow up to relay the information to the rest of the team would be cool too.

also thanks for bringing up these considerations kat. in general we just got through main designs, then spec, and will need to circle back to things like loader, error states, etc. trent would be great to have you account for loading states in your work. an on error states, we’ll need to have someone do a pass and identify and design for error states when we’ve got a bit more free time from the design team, likely when onboarding is completed

I understand, but the sooner the better :slightly_smiling_face: we’re already building in loading states that might have to change based on these decisions. And based on the estimates, we really don’t have time to go back and fix things.
ok! i will move as fast as i can

That’s an interesting idea. usually, i’d say icons should be in the center of containers, but shit. I couldn’t say for sure without trying it
it creates a weird visual layout where they feel super spaced out
Also, rather than spec'ing it off-centered, we can create the assets to fit that positioning which is easier for dev to implement. I've done that with icons in the past.
If that makes sense
Basically the asset is the size of the tap target and you place the actual icon where you want it
Again, whichever is easier for implementation and regularity of assets

in trying to build a comfortable area to tap each icon, this is a tricky balance between visual layout and designing the interaction layer, curious to know if the intended spacing in the red lines creates any issues or if we think the positioning of the icons should change
if we can export with the padding built in, but still making the inside padding closer, would there be an issue with the asymmetrical spacing?
<@U1A1A9L7N>  Totally makes sense.
